block.p: Bush Calls for Global Goal In Curbing Greenhouse Gas President Bush, fending off international accusations that he was ignoring climate change, proposed for the first time to set ''a long-term global goal'' for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, and he called on other industrial nations to join the United States in negotiations aimed at reaching an agreement.
U.S. Official Assails Putin A top Russia expert at the State Department issued an unusually sharp public criticism of Moscow's behavior under President Vladimir V. Putin.

New Twist in Poisoning Case The suspect in the fatal poisoning of Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer and Kremlin critic who died last year in Britain, said Britain's foreign intelligence agency and a self-exiled Russian tycoon had organized the killing and framed him to create a political scandal.

Hunting for Kidnapped Britons The search for five British civilians kidnapped from an Iraqi government building intensified with American troops conducting raids in Sadr City, a Shiite stronghold, and the Iraqi government pledging its support for an investigation.

Union to Weigh Israel Boycott A movement in Britain to boycott Israel economically gathered pace as the country's biggest labor union said it would follow the union of university instructors in weighing punitive measures against Israel.

New U.S.-India Nuclear Talks Talks intended to restart negotiations on a landmark nuclear pact between India and the United States began in New Delhi amid disagreement over India's right to continue testing nuclear weapons.

Officials Identify Man With Dangerous TB The man with a dangerous form of tuberculosis who flew to Europe for his wedding and honeymoon was identified as a 31-year-old Atlanta lawyer. Department of Homeland Security officials said he re-entered the country from Canada when a customs agent let him pass despite knowing that the man was being sought by health authorities. A1
Secret Program is Under Fire The Senate Intelligence Committee questioned the continuing value of the Central Intelligence Agency's secret interrogation program for terrorism suspects.

Agent in Leak Case Sues C.I.A. Valerie Wilson, the former intelligence operative at the heart of an investigation that reached into the White House, sued the Central Intelligence Agency over its refusal to allow her to publish a memoir that would discuss how long she had worked for the agency.

Gene Scientist's DNA Decoded The full genome of James D. Watson, who jointly discovered the structure of DNA in 1953, has been deciphered, marking what scientists believe is the gateway to an impending era of personalized genomic medicine.
Library Dedicated to Minister Hundreds of friends, family members, ministers and politicians gathered to dedicate a library commemorating the ministry of the evangelist Billy Graham. A16

Increase in Minority Students The nation's minority student population, driven by an extraordinary influx of Hispanics, surged to 42 percent of public school enrollment, up from 22 percent three decades ago, according to an annual report.

Columbia Will Let State Oversee Student Aid Office Columbia University will pay $1.1 million to a fund to educate students about loans and has agreed to have its financial aid office monitored by state officials for five years, under a settlement reached with the New York State attorney general.

New Jersey Pension Inquiry The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into New Jersey's handling of its pension fund for public employees, suggesting that federal regulators are concerned that the state treasury did not properly disclose its contributions to the fund.

Bancrofts Open to a Sale In a remarkable turnaround, the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, agreed to meet with Rupert Murdoch, just weeks after the family rejected an initial $5 billion takeover offer from Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation.

Law Firm's Founder May Go William S. Lerach is considering leaving the law firm he founded. While the exact reasons behind his career considerations remain unclear, it suggests that the investigation into accusations of kickbacks paid to class-action plaintiffs has gained momentum.

Google and Privacy Issues A feature in Google's map service that allows users to zoom in on urban images is raising privacy concerns. But Google said it had consulted with public service organizations in designing the service.

William Meredith A Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who used the rigorous constraints of meter and rhyme to subdue some of the most uncontrollable aspects of the human condition -- fear, loneliness, destiny, mortality -- he was 88. A23
Editorials: Ahead of the Group of 8 meeting, talking about warming and a real plan for AIDS; witness protection; knowledgeable furniture.
